title: How to Precook Bacon

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 400 °F (204 °C).
steps.description: If you have an electric oven, you'll probably need to wait 10 to 15 minutes until it reaches the right temperature. Gas ovens take a bit shorter to preheat—around 5 to 10 minutes. Modern ovens typically beep when the oven is the proper temperature, while others have a light that turns on—usually next to the temperature dial. Keep your oven rack in the middle slot.

steps.headline: Cover a baking sheet with heavy-duty aluminum foil.
steps.description: Place a piece of aluminum foil over your baking sheet. Cut it about 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) from the edge of the pan. Afterwards, press down the foil onto the sheet, applying pressure near the inner perimeter with your fingers. Wrap the extra portion of the foil tightly over the outer perimeter of the pan. An alternative technique is to fold up your aluminum foil like an accordion, with each lump about 1 inch (2.5 cm) high. Afterwards, place your bacon on the peaks of each lump. This is best if you prefer your bacon meaty and tough.

steps.headline: Line your bacon strips one at a time vertically onto your baking sheet.
steps.description: Start from one end of the pan and move to the opposite end—left to right, or right to left—placing each strip straight and vertical onto the aluminum foil. After the first piece, ensure that each subsequent bacon strip covers about half of the previous strip. Straighten any crooked pieces after you lay down the strips.

steps.headline: Bake your strips at 400 °F (204 °C) for 20 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: You can increase the temperature to 425 °F (218 °C), but don't go any higher. Be careful to watch your bacon closely so that they don't overcook. After 20 to 25 minutes, the bacon should be slightly undercooked, which is ideal for precooked bacon that you're going to reheat later. If you prefer more tender bacon, cook your strips at 375 °F (191 °C) for about 35 minutes. After precooking, your bacon should be flexible—not too crisp—in order to properly reheat them.

steps.headline: Remove the strips from the oven and separate them.
steps.description: Use a fork the gently separate each of the bacon strips immediately after removing them the sheet from the oven. This will prevent the strips from sticking to each other. Let your bacon strips cool for about 5 minutes after removing them from the oven.

steps.headline: Drain your bacon on a stack of paper towels prior and set the tinfoil aside.
steps.description: Place a few paper towels down onto a flat surface and place your bacon pieces onto them. Let them sit for about 5 minutes to give the paper towels enough time to soak up the excess grease. An alternative is placing your bacon onto a baking rack that rests on top of a sheet pan. Although it takes a bit longer, the grease should drip down.

steps.headline: Store your bacon grease in the refrigerator to enjoy later.
steps.description: Fold the tinfoil in half and slowly pour the leftover bacon fat into a small glass container. Afterwards, place it in the fridge—it should solidify quickly. Spread bacon fat onto bread for a nice alternative to butter. Bacon fat will remain good for up to 1 year as long as it is stored in a clean, airtight container. Be sure to remove any bacon bits prior to storage—they can turn the fat rancid in a matter of weeks.

steps.headline: Store your precooked bacon in the refrigerator for 4 to 5 days at most.
steps.description: If you're freeing your bacon strips, put them in the refrigerator to cool for about 20 to 30 minutes before doing so—this will chill them and prevent them from thawing other items in the freezer. If you're going to keep your bacon pieces in the refrigerator for longer, wrap them tightly in plastic wrap or heavy-duty aluminum foil and then store them in an airtight container. After 4 to 5 days, either re-heat and eat your bacon or freeze them for long-term storage.

steps.headline: Line wax paper onto a baking sheet and layer your bacon on.
steps.description: After filling each piece of wax paper with your bacon, place another layer on top of the bacon and continue layering more bacon on top. Continue this process until all of the bacon is on top of wax paper. Place a final piece of wax paper on top of your bacon.

steps.headline: Put the baking sheet into the freezer for at least 2 to 3 hours.
steps.description: Ideally, keep it in the freezer overnight. Once they've frozen, remove them and separate them onto a plate. From here, you can store them in Ziploc bags.

steps.headline: Place your bacon into a Ziploc bag and freeze them for up to 4 months.

steps.headline: Reheat your frozen bacon in the microwave for about 30 seconds.
steps.description: When you're ready to enjoy our bacon, put it in the microwave for about 30 seconds. If you want to bake them, place them in a preheated oven and bake the at 400 °F (204 °C) for about 5 minutes or until they're crispy. Add your bacon to burgers and sandwiches, or cut it into small pieces and sprinkle it onto salad, pasta, or fried rice.
